entry.title: üî¥ [15] biophysics - biorXiv Preprints ‚ñ∂ A moments-based approach for inferring mechanisms of transcriptional regulation using nascent RNA data
entry.summary: Unraveling the kinetics of transcriptional regulation is a central challenge in molecular biology. Traditional inference methods based on cell-to-cell mRNA variability are limited because mRNA levels
entry.content:
AI Decision: Presents a moments-based theoretical framework using nascent RNA measurements to infer and select among transcriptional regulation models, improving kinetic parameter estimation versus mature mRNA data.

Abstract: Unraveling the kinetics of transcriptional regulation is a central challenge in molecular biology. Traditional inference methods based on cell-to-cell mRNA variability are limited because mRNA levels reflect not only transcriptional activity but also post-transcriptional processes. Recent advances in quantifying nascent RNAs across isogenic cells provide a more direct readout of transcriptional dynamics. Here, we present a moments-based theoretical framework that leverages nascent RNA data to infer transcriptional kinetics. We derive closed-form expressions for the first two time-dependent moments of nascent RNA across three canonical transcription models and demonstrate that nascent RNA exhibits distinct transient overshoots and higher Fano factors compared to mature mRNA. Through analysis of synthetic datasets, we show that these features enable more accurate estimation of transcriptional kinetics and allow reliable model selection, distinguishing single from multi-pathway promoter activation with over 75% accuracy even from small sample sizes. We further validated our model selection method using real experimental transcription datasets in yeast and E. coli cells, with nascent RNA demonstrating superior performance in identifying cross-talk pathway regulation. Our framework thus offers a computationally efficient and mechanistically informative approach for decoding transcriptional dynamics, emphasizing the advantages of time-dependent nascent RNA measurements over mature mRNA in capturing the true kinetics of transcriptional regulation.

Links found: No links found

entry.content:
AI Decision: Proposes a heuristic origin-of-life mechanism in which homochirality emerges during prebiotic phospholipid bilayer vesicle formation at the water‚Äìair interface, potentially linking lipid self-assembly with the chiral selection of key biomolecules.

Abstract: Life demonstrates remarkable homochirality of its major building blocks: nucleic acids, amino acids, sugars, and phospholipids. We propose a mechanism that places the root of life homochirality in the formation of phospholipid bilayer vesicles (liposomes). entry.summary: Lava tubes, or subsurface conduits formed by volcanic activity, have emerged as critical geological features for understanding planetary evolution and for supporting future human space exploration. Th
entry.content:

Abstract: Lava tubes, or subsurface conduits formed by volcanic activity, have emerged as critical geological features for understanding planetary evolution and for supporting future human space exploration. This paper provides an integrated review of the formation, morphology, and preservation of lava tubes on Earth, the Moon, and Mars, emphasizing their geological significance and habitability potential. entry.title: üü† [55] cell biology - biorXiv Preprints ‚ñ∂ Nucleolar reorganization on stress depends on physicochemical changes due to nascent rRNA synthesis
entry.summary: Successive maturation of ribosomal subunits occurs through multi-layered phase-separated structures of the cell nucleolus. The spatio-functional relationship between transcription of rRNA and nucleola
entry.content:
AI Decision: Using expansion microscopy, this study shows that nucleolar phase-separated subcompartments reorganize under stress primarily due to reduced nascent rRNA synthesis, driving a viscoelastic-to-solid-like transition and altered nucleolar physicochemical gradients rather than active repair signaling.

Abstract: Successive maturation of ribosomal subunits occurs through multi-layered phase-separated structures of the cell nucleolus. The spatio-functional relationship between transcription of rRNA and nucleolar substructures and how this adapts to cellular stress remain incompletely understood. In this study, we resolve the sub nucleolar structures using expansion microscopy to reveal ordered structures of fibrillar center (FC) and dense fibrillar component (DFC) domains as nested shells, which is reorganized upon cellular stress like DNA damage or RNA polymerase I (RNAPI) inhibition. Direct visualization of nascent (5' ETS) and mature (28S) rRNA suggested that rRNA synthesis is the critical regulator of nucleolar size, and organization. Nucleolar reorganization upon stress emerges to be a direct function of nascent rRNA levels. Stress-induced transcription inhibition remodels the sub-nucleolar compartments from a viscoelastic state into solid-like condensates thereby perturbing the nucleolar pH gradient due to the missing rRNA scaffold. We show, that rather than signalling to mediate rDNA repair, nucleolar reorganization naturally arises primarily from reduced rRNA levels and the resultant biophysical restructuring of the nucleolus under cellular stress.

entry.summary: Ooids are small spheroidal carbonate grains that have circularly concentric and radially aligned crystals. Oolitic carbonates are commonly associated with fossils or organic matter, which has led to h
entry.content:
AI Decision: This study argues that carbonate ooids can form via abiotic chemically oscillating reactions while preserving authigenic microbial biomass, sharpening how we interpret carbonate-embedded biosignatures (and potential false positives) through Earth history.

Abstract: Ooids are small spheroidal carbonate grains that have circularly concentric and radially aligned crystals. Oolitic carbonates are commonly associated with fossils or organic matter, which has led to hypothetical formation models involving both biological and abiotic processes. The most commonly invoked model involves precipitates from supersaturated CaCO3 water under high-energy conditions. However, this model does [‚Ä¶] The post Authigenic Biosignatures Of Microbial Biomass Preserved As Carbonate Ooids Formed By Abiotic Chemically Oscillating Reactions Throughout Earth History appeared first on Astrobiology .

entry.title: üî¥ [25] Phys.org: Evolution News ‚ñ∂ Flowering plant origins: Dosage-sensitive genes suggest no whole-genome duplications in ancestral angiosperm
entry.summary: Angiosperms, also known as flowering plants, represent the most diverse group of seed plants, and their origin and evolution have long been a central question in plant evolutionary biology. Whole-geno
entry.content:
AI Decision: This study argues that dosage-sensitive gene patterns imply no ancestral whole-genome duplication at the base of angiosperms, informing plant evolutionary history but offering minimal direct insight into origins-of-life processes.

Abstract: Angiosperms, also known as flowering plants, represent the most diverse group of seed plants, and their origin and evolution have long been a central question in plant evolutionary biology. Whole-genome duplication (WGD), or polyploidization, is widely recognized as a key driver of the origin and trait evolution of both seed plants and angiosperms.

Links found: No links found

Read source article

entry.title: üî¥ [0] Phys.org: Evolution News ‚ñ∂ Evidence of upright walking found in 7-million-year-old Sahelanthropus fossils
entry.summary: In recent decades, scientists have debated whether a seven-million-year-old fossil was bipedal‚Äîa trait that would make it the oldest human ancestor. A new analysis by a team of anthropologists offers
entry.content:
AI Decision: Anthropological analysis suggesting 7-million-year-old Sahelanthropus tchadensis was bipedal, informing early hominin evolution rather than origins-of-life or astrobiology.

Abstract: In recent decades, scientists have debated whether a seven-million-year-old fossil was bipedal‚Äîa trait that would make it the oldest human ancestor. A new analysis by a team of anthropologists offers powerful evidence that Sahelanthropus tchadensis‚Äîa species discovered in the early 2000s‚Äîwas indeed bipedal by uncovering a feature found only in bipedal hominins.

Links found: No links found

entry.title: üî¥ [20] Phys.org: Evolution News ‚ñ∂ Two white-blooded fish, two paths: Icefish and noodlefish independently lose red blood cell function
entry.summary: Antarctic icefish are famous for living without red blood cells, but they are not alone. A species of needle-shaped, warm-water fish called the Asian noodlefish also lacks hemoglobin and red blood cel
entry.content:
AI Decision: Compares two fish lineages that independently evolved loss of hemoglobin/red blood cell function, offering an evolutionary physiology case study with only indirect relevance to origins-of-life questions.

Abstract: Antarctic icefish are famous for living without red blood cells, but they are not alone. A species of needle-shaped, warm-water fish called the Asian noodlefish also lacks hemoglobin and red blood cells. Like icefish, its veins are filled with translucent white blood, said H. William Detrich, professor emeritus of marine and environmental sciences, who collaborated with Chinese scientists on a paper about the strange aquatic creatures published in Current Biology.
